responses.rationale: The segment describes the virus as 'voracious' and a 'global zoonotic animal pandemic', which are not explicit calming cues.
The segment uses the term 'collateral damage', which is not an explicit calming cue.
The segment states humans can be infected and that the situation 'could all change quickly', which are not explicit calming cues.
The segment discusses the virus's mutation rate but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment discusses mutations and states they 'don't always work in favor of the virus' and often 'won't work or be fit enough', which are bare positive facts, not explicit calming.
The segment discusses mutations and potential advantages for the virus but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment discusses the potential for the pandemic to become a 'major problem for people', which is not an explicit calming cue.
The segment describes animal cases but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment describes animal symptoms but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment describes severe animal symptoms ('Screaming very loud, whole-body tremors') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment describes animal symptoms ('get longer and longer') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a fact about animal infection but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a fact about animal infection routes but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes a source describing the 'severity of the seizures' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes a source describing the disease progression as a 'very sad thing to see' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports that human infections have been 'sporadic and usually self-limiting', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment reports the virus 'can still be deadly' and fatality rates, alongside the bare positive fact that it 'isn't particularly good at infecting humans'. No explicit calming cues.
The segment reports the virus 'rarely gets passed to someone else', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment uses the technical term 'dead-end infections' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment explains how a 'dead-end infection' happens but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment explains why the virus is 'not a virus that's well-adapted to humans', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment reports facts about human cases but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports symptoms of human cases but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a potential exposure route but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports symptoms of a human case but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports that cases 'were successfully treated', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment reports that cases 'None developed severe symptoms or infected others', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment reports that the virus 'is unlikely to transmit through the air', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment describes an experiment setup but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment describes an experiment setup but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment describes an experiment outcome ('all of them became ill') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment describes an experiment setup but contains no explicit calming cues.

The segment reports experiment outcomes and conclusions ('not well adapted to respiratory spread', 'seems to be what's happening in the real world'), which are bare positive facts, not explicit calming.
The segment reports facts about herd infections and human cases ('number of human infections has apparently been low') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes the CDC stating 'These early ferret experiments are good news', which is an explicit calming cue.
The segment reports an agency plan but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment warns that the situation 'could change' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment warns about the virus's opportunity to change but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes an expert stating viruses 'can change very quickly' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes an expert stating viruses 'can adapt, and they can spread very easily' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a fact about human immunity but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes an expert stating existing immunity 'is not necessarily going to protect us' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment describes study findings as 'sobering' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports an experiment outcome ('killed all the ferrets') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports that human cases 'have been mild' but also that 'it is possible that there will be serious illnesses'. No explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on the spectrum of severity in human infections but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on the spectrum of severity in human infections but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports an expert opinion on symptom severity but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports an expert's limitation but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a bare positive fact about immunity ('memory cells... might recognize parts') but lacks explicit calming language.
The segment reports uncertainty ('difficult to predict') and the importance of vaccination but lacks explicit calming language.
The segment reports on vaccine availability and preparation, which is preparedness, but lacks an explicit link to public safety required for Q5.
The segment reports on vaccine orders and use to 'protect workers', which is preparedness linked to a specific group's safety, but not the general public/consumer safety required for Q5.

The segment reports the CDC's assessment that the 'risk to the general public from H5N1 is low'. This is a bare low-risk statement without an intensifier or other explicit calming keywords required for Q5.
The segment reports on the availability of protective equipment and funding, which is preparedness/support, but lacks an explicit link to public safety required for Q5.
The segment reports on challenges with implementing precautions but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on the development of a rapid test, which is preparedness, but lacks an explicit link to public safety required for Q5.
The segment reports an expert opinion on symptom severity but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on the potential for severe disease but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a characteristic of the virus ('able to infect a number of internal organs') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a characteristic of the virus ('doesn't just locate... in the lungs') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports a characteristic of the virus ('found in 'the brains and then the spleens, the intestines, and the heart') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports expert agreement but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes an expert calling the virus 'at the top of the list in terms of bad guy viruses' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on animal behavior but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports that the virus 'hasn't made the changes' to become a human pathogen, which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment quotes an expert's perspective but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes an expert's perspective on the virus's changes and lack of evidence for human-to-human transmission but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on animal outcomes ('all of them died') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on animal outcomes ('survived, but they ultimately went blind') but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on the effectiveness of precautions ('grateful they were effective'). 'Grateful' is not listed as an explicit calming keyword.
The segment reports that they 'never spread the virus', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.

The segment reports a bare positive fact ('never spread the virus') but also includes a comparison to the start of Covid ('Unfortunately, it's kind of like when Covid went through'), which is not calming.
The segment reports a current status ('hasn't encountered any infected animals') but also vigilance ('watching the news closely', 'could easily see H5N1 again'). No explicit calming cues.
The segment states farmers are 'on edge' and the virus is 'on the rise'. No explicit calming cues.
The segment discusses rising prices and a 'new virus'. No explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on disease precautions preventing a visit but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports it's 'rare for people to get infected', which is a bare low-risk fact, not explicit calming.

The segment reports an organization is 'watching the outbreak closely' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports that affected poultry 'do need to be de-populated' but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports that depopulation 'stops the virus', which is a bare positive fact about an action, not explicit calming.
The segment quotes a source stating 'We don’t want the farm spreading the virus', which is a goal, not an explicit calming cue.
The segment identifies the speaker but contains no explicit calming cues.

The segment reports industry status but contains no explicit calming cues.

The segment reports no outbreak yet but also that they are 'anxiously watching'. No explicit calming cues.

The segment reports an expected outcome ('expected to stop') based on actions and migration, which is a bare positive expectation, not explicit calming.
The segment reports on preparations to destroy hens and describes it as the 'biggest outbreak to date'. No explicit calming cues.
The segment reports on the discovery of bird flu and an 'increase of deaths'. No explicit calming cues.
The segment reports that the 'majority of the flock could be spared', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment quotes a source stating the 'whole (population of the) hall will have to be culled' but contains no explicit calming cues.

The segment quotes an FDA spokesperson stating the study 'should not be used to draw any conclusions about the safety of the U.S. milk supply'. This is a bare negation about drawing negative conclusions, not an explicit statement that the milk supply is safe.
The segment reports FDA testing found 'none yielded live virus', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment reports agencies are 'conducting pasteurization studies', which is action/preparedness, but lacks an explicit link to public safety required for Q5.
The segment reports USDA testing results ('no samples of ground beef... tested positive', 'particles... detected in one'). Mixed findings, no explicit calming.
The segment reports agency action ('prevented the animal from entering the food supply'), which is action, but lacks an explicit link to public safety required for Q5.
The segment describes a study method but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports study results ('still had detectable levels', 'did not'). Mixed findings, no explicit calming.

The segment reports on separating sick animals but contains no explicit calming cues.
The segment reports animals 'appear to recover', which is a bare positive fact, not explicit calming.
The segment quotes an expert stating 'It’s not a food safety concern'. This is a bare negation of 'safety concern', not an explicit statement using 'safe'.

The segment reports a company statement that there was 'no risk to eggs' and 'no eggs had been recalled'. 'No risk' is a bare negation/low-risk statement.

The segment reports experts 'cautioned that the situation could change'. Caution is not a calming cue.
The segment quotes an expert describing the situation as an 'emerging issue' with 'a lot that we don’t know'. No explicit calming cues.
The segment quotes an expert stating 'everybody is trying to figure it out as quickly as possible'. No explicit calming cues.
